instruction: What metric was chosen to estimate soil characteristics and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to estimate soil characteristics was the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The RMSE values were used to compare the accuracy of the estimated soil properties with the actual values. The study found that the ML algorithms, specifically MLP-UAV networks and MLP-S2A networks, provided improvements in the RMSE values for different soil characteristics. The RMSE values improved between 23.23% and 35.66% for sand, silt, and soil organic matter content in MLP-UAV networks, while the MLP-S2A networks provided 9.73% to 19.85% improvement for pH, clay, and soil moisture. The UAV-based GBDT ML algorithms were even more successful, with relative improvements ranging from 12.16% to 93.66% for pH, sand, silt, CaCO3, and soil moisture. Therefore, the RMSE metric was used to evaluate the accuracy of the estimation models, and the study showed significant improvements in estimation accuracy using the ML algorithms and sensor technology.

instruction: What were the results of comparing the performance of Multi-Layer Perception Artificial Neural Network (MLP-ANN) and Gradient Descent Boosting Tree (GDBT) machine learning algorithms in estimating soil characteristics using remote sensing data from unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) and Sentinel 2A optical satellite images?
Output:
The results of comparing the performance of MLP-ANN and GDBT machine learning algorithms in estimating soil characteristics using remote sensing data from UAV and Sentinel 2A optical satellite images showed that both algorithms were effective in improving the estimation accuracy. 

In the case of MLP-UAV networks, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) values improved between 23.23% and 35.66% for sand, silt, and soil organic matter content. On the other hand, the MLP-S2A networks provided 9.73% to 19.85% improvement for pH, clay, and soil moisture (SM).

In terms of GDBT ML algorithms, the RMSE values in UAV-based models were more successful in estimating pH, sand, silt, CaCO3, and SM compared to the S2A models. The relative improvement ranged between 12.16% and 93.66%.

These results indicate that both MLP-ANN and GDBT algorithms, when combined with remote sensing data from UAV and Sentinel 2A, can significantly enhance the estimation accuracy of various soil characteristics.

instruction: How do the different optimization techniques and estimation algorithms used in this study affect the accuracy of soil characteristic estimation using machine learning algorithms and remote sensing data from unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) and Sentinel 2A optical satellite images?
Output:
The study found that different optimization techniques and estimation algorithms have an impact on the accuracy of soil characteristic estimation using machine learning algorithms and remote sensing data from UAV and Sentinel 2A optical satellite images.

Firstly, the use of Multi-Layer Perception Artificial Neural Network (MLP-ANN) and Gradient Descent Boosting Tree (GDBT) ML algorithms improved the estimation of soil characteristics. The MLP-ANN and GDBT ML algorithms were employed to enhance the estimation accuracy.

Secondly, Bayesian optimization was used to optimize the hyperparameters of the GDBT ML algorithm. This optimization technique helped improve the accuracy of soil characteristic estimation.

Furthermore, the study compared the performance of estimation between UAV-based models and S2A models. The results showed that the UAV-based GBDT ML algorithms were more successful in estimating certain soil characteristics such as pH, sand, silt, CaCO3, and soil moisture (SM) compared to the S2A models. The relative improvement in estimation accuracy ranged from 12.16% to 93.66%.
